Description: Head of terracotta bearded figure of Hadrian with wreath. A portrait head broken from a group of Hadrian, crowned with a laurel wreath held in the hand of Nike, who otherwise is totally lost. The hair, but not the crown, is indicated at the back. Hollow; two-piece mould. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV Bibliog. Fischer 1994: no. 982; Bailey 1996a: 210, fig. 2. A possible occasion for the manufacture of such a figure is the defeat of the Jewish Revolt in ad 118: this uprising had a profound and damaging effect in Egypt, as elsewhere. Comparandum. A slightly more complete example in Tübingen, from the same or a parallel mould, shows that Hadrian was wearing a chlamys (paludamentum) and thus may be a cuirassed figure (Fischer 1994: no. 982 = Vogt 1924: pl. xliii:2). See Bailey, Archaeological Research in Roman Egypt, 1993
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3508)
